dwellings may develop and implement reasonable occupancy and safety standards based on factors such as the number and size of sleeping areas or bedrooms and overall size of a dwelling unit as long as the standards do not violate local state or federal restrictions nothing in this article prohibits the rental application or similar document from requiring information concerning the number ages sex and familial relationship of the applicants and the dwellings intended occupants    housing commission powers a the housing commission has the power for the purposes of this article to initiate and receive complaints conduct investigations of any violation of this article attempt resolution of complaints by conference and conciliation issue a charge and refer it to the city attorney for action or at any stage of the complaint process refer the complaint to the state real estate board andor the united states department of housing and urban development b any respondent may file an answer to a complaint complaints and answers must be made in writing under oath or affirmation and in such form as the commission requires complaints and answers may be reasonably and fairly amended at any time c upon the filing of a complaint or the initiation of a complaint by the commission or its designee the commission shall provide written notice to the parties as follows 1 to the aggrieved person acknowledging the filing and advising such person of the time limits and choice of forums under this article  and 2 to the respondent not later than ten days after such filing or the identification of an additional respondent under subsection b of this section identifying the alleged discriminatory housing practice and advising such respondent of the procedural rights and obligations of respondents under this article with a copy of the original complaint and copies of any supporting documentation referenced in the complaint    complaint filing a requirements a complaint under section 2285 shall be filed with the commission in writing within one year after the alleged discriminatory housing practice occurred or terminated b additional or substitute respondents any person not named in the complaint who is identified as a respondent in the course of the investigation may be joined as an additional or substitute respondent upon written notice to such person by the commission explaining the basis for the commissions belief that such person is properly joined as a respondent  procedures for investigation of complaints a the commission shall commence proceedings with respect to a complaint within 30 days after receipt of the complaint and shall complete the investigation within 100 days thereof unless it is impracticable to do so if the commission is unable to complete the investigation within 100 days after the receipt of the complaint the aggrieved person and the respondent shall be notified in writing of the reasons for not doing so  however in no event shall the investigation extend beyond one year from the receipt of the complaint by the commission b when conducting an investigation of a complaint filed under this article the commission shall have the right to interview any person who may have any information which may further its investigation and to request production of any records and documents for inspection and copying in the possession of any person which may further the investigation such persons shall be interviewed under oath the commission by majority vote with the advice of the city attorney shall have the power to issue and serve a subpoena to any such person to appear and testify and to produce any such records or documents for inspection and copying said subpoenas and discovery may be ordered to the same extent and subject to the same limitations as would apply if the subpoenas or discovery were ordered or served as part of a civil action in the commonwealth in case of refusal or neglect to obey a subpoena the commission may refer this matter to the city attorney if necessary in order to take appropriate action to petition for its enforcement in the circuit court for the county the hearing on such petition shall be given priority on the court docket over all cases which are not otherwise given priority on the court docket by law c at the end of each investigation under this section the commission shall prepare a final investigative report containing 1 the names and dates of contacts with witnesses  2 a summary and the dates of correspondence and other contacts with the aggrieved person and the respondent  3 a summary description of other pertinent records  4 a summary of witness statements  and 5 answers to interrogatories a final report under this subsection may be amended if additional evidence is later discovered d the commission shall make available to the aggrieved person and the respondent at any time upon request following completion of the commissions investigation information derived from an investigation and any final investigative report relating to that investigation    reasonable cause determination the commission shall within 100 days after the filing of a complaint determine based on the facts and after consultation with the office of the city attorney whether reasonable cause exists to believe that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur unless it is impracticable to do so or unless the commission has approved a conciliation agreement with respect to the complaint in no event however shall the investigation be extended beyond one year from the receipt of the complaint by the commission    no reasonable cause determination if the commission determines that no reasonable cause exists to believe that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur the commission shall promptly dismiss the complaint notifying the parties within 30 days of such determination the commission shall make public disclosure of each dismissal    conciliation during the period beginning with the filing of such complaint and ending with the filing of a charge or a dismissal by the commission the commission shall to the extent feasible engage in conciliation with respect to such complaint 1 a conciliation agreement arising out of such conciliation shall be an agreement between the respondent and the complainant and shall be subject to approval by the commission 2 a conciliation agreement may provide for binding arbitration of the dispute arising from the complaint any such arbitration that results from a conciliation agreement may award appropriate relief including monetary relief 3 each conciliation agreement shall be made public unless the complainant and respondent otherwise agree and the commission determines that disclosure is not required to further the purposes of this article 4 whenever the commission has reasonable cause to believe that a respondent has breached a conciliation agreement the commission may refer the matter to the city attorney with a recommendation that a civil action be filed under section 2294 for the enforcement of such agreement 5 any and all information not otherwise admissible in a court of law derived from the investigation the investigative report or the copy of the proposed conciliation agreement to which one or more parties objected shall be precluded from use as evidence in any subsequent proceedings in arbitration or in a court of competent jurisdiction    issuance of charge upon failure to resolve a complaint by conciliation and after consultation with the office of the city attorney the commission shall issue a charge on behalf of the aggrieved person and shall immediately refer the charge to the city attorney who shall consider proceeding with the charge as directed by section 2293 the commission may not issue a charge under this section regarding an alleged discriminatory housing practice after the beginning of a trial of a civil action commenced by the aggrieved party under an act of congress or a state law seeking relief with respect to that discriminatory housing practice 1 such charge a shall consist of a short and plain statement of the facts upon which the commission has found reasonable cause to believe that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur  b shall be based on the final investigative report  and c need not be limited to the acts or ground alleged in the complaint filed under section 2286 2 after the commission issues a charge under this section the commission shall cause a copy thereof to be served on each respondent named in such charge and on each aggrieved person on whose behalf the complaint was filed    prompt judicial action if the commission concludes at any time following the filing of a complaint and after consultation with the office of the city attorney that prompt judicial action is necessary to carry out the purpose of this article the commission may authorize a civil action by the city attorney for appropriate temporary or preliminary relief upon receipt of such authorization the city attorney shall promptly consider commencing and maintaining such action any temporary restraining order or other order granting preliminary or temporary relief shall be issued in accordance with the virginia rules of civil procedure the commencement of a civil action under this section shall not affect the initiation or continuation of administrative proceedings by the commission under section 2285    civil action by city attorneycharge by housing commission a not later than 30 days after a charge is referred by the commission to the city attorney under section 2291 the city attorney shall reach a final decision on whether to commence and maintain a civil action seeking relief on behalf of the complainant in the circuit court for the county b any aggrieved person with respect to the issues to be determined in such a civil action pursuant to subsection a of this section may intervene as of right c in a civil action under this section if the court finds that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur the court may grant as relief any relief which a court could grant with respect to such discriminatory housing practice in a civil action under section 2295 any relief so granted that would accrue to an aggrieved person under section 2295 shall also accrue to the aggrieved person in a civil action under this section if monetary relief is sought for the benefit of an aggrieved person who does not intervene in the civil action the court shall not award such relief if that aggrieved person has not complied with discovery orders entered by the court in the course of the action brought under this section d in any court proceeding arising under this section the court in its discretion may allow reasonable attorneys fees and costs    samepractices of resistance to article provisions a issues of public importance whenever the city attorney has reasonable cause to believe that any person or group of persons is engaged in a pattern or practice of resistance to the full enjoyment of any of the rights granted by this article or that any group of persons has been denied any of the rights granted by this article and such denial raises an issue of general public importance the city attorney may commence a civil action in the appropriate circuit court for appropriate relief b breach of a conciliation agreement in the event of a breach of a conciliation agreement by a respondent the commission may authorize a civil action by the city attorney the city attorney may commence a civil action in any appropriate circuit court for appropriate relief a civil action under this subsection shall be commenced no later than the expiration of 90 days after the referral of such alleged breach c subpoena the city attorney on behalf of the commission or other party at whose request a subpoena is issued under this article may enforce such subpoena in appropriate proceedings in the appropriate circuit court d relief penalties in a civil action under subsections a and b of this section the court may 1 award such preventive relief including a permanent or temporary injunction restraining order or other order against the person responsible for a violation of this article as is necessary to ensure the full enjoyment of the rights granted by this article  2 award such other relief as the court deems appropriate including compensatory and punitive damages to the person aggrieved  3 assess a civil penalty against the respondent a in an amount not exceeding $5000000 for a first violation  and b in an amount not exceeding $10000000 for any subsequent violation  4 award the complainant when the prevailing party reasonable attorneys fees and costs the defendant may be awarded such fees and costs if the complaint was brought in bad faith and without any basis e other aggrieved persons upon timely application any person may intervene in a civil action commenced by the city attorney under subsection a or b of this section which involves an alleged discriminatory housing practice with respect to which such person is an aggrieved person or a party to a conciliation agreement the court may grant such appropriate relief to any such intervening party as is authorized to be granted to a plaintiff in a civil action under section 2295    civil action  enforcement by private parties a an aggrieved person may commence a civil action in an appropriate state court not later than two years after the occurrence or the termination of an alleged discriminatory housing practice or the breach of a conciliation agreement entered into under this article whichever occurs last to obtain appropriate relief with respect to such discriminatory housing practice or breach b an aggrieved person may commence a civil action under this section no later than 180 days after the conclusion of the administrative process with respect to a complaint or charge or not later than two years after the occurrence or the termination of an alleged discriminatory housing practice whichever is later this subsection shall not apply to actions arising from a breach of a conciliation agreement an aggrieved person may commence a civil action under this section whether or not a complaint has been filed under section 2286 and without regard to the status of any such complaint if the commission or a state or federal agency has obtained a conciliation agreement with the consent of an aggrieved person no action may be filed under this section by such aggrieved person with respect to the alleged discriminatory housing practice which forms the basis for such complaint except for the purpose of enforcing the terms of such an agreement c in a civil action under subsection a of this section if the court finds that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur the court may award to the plaintiff as the prevailing party compensatory and punitive damages reasonable attorneys fees and costs and subject to subsection d of this section may grant as relief any permanent or temporary injunction temporary restraining order or other order including an order enjoining the defendant from engaging in such practice or order such affirmative action as may be appropriate d relief granted under subsection c of this section shall not affect any contract sale encumbrance or lease consummated before the granting of such relief and involving bona fide purchasers encumbrancers or tenants without actual notice of the filing of a complaint with the commission or civil action under this article e upon timely application the city attorney may intervene in such civil action if the city attorney certifies that the case is of general public importance upon intervention the city attorney may obtain such relief as would be available to the private party under subsection c of this section    witness fees witnesses summoned by a subpoena under this article shall be entitled to the same witness and mileage fees as witnesses in proceedings in the courts of the commonwealth fees payable to a witness summoned by a subpoena issued at the request of a party shall be paid by that party or where a party is unable to pay the fees by the commission    additional powers of the commission a in any case in which the commission has received or initiated a complaint and conducted an investigation of any violation of this article and determined that there exists a reasonable cause to believe that a licensed broker salesperson rental location agent or agency has engaged in discriminatory housing practices prohibited by the virginia fair housing law section 36961 et seq or the virginia equal credit opportunity act section 5912119 et seq the commission shall refer the matter to the state real estate board b the commission shall perform all acts necessary and proper to carry out the provisions of this article and may promulgate and amend necessary regulations    construction of law nothing in this article shall abridge the federal fair housing act of 196 as amended 42 usc 3601 et seq    secs 229922126  reserved article v  residential landlordtenant relations definitions the terms landlord owner tenant rent rental agreement and other terms used in this article and by the housing commission carry the same definitions as are contained in virginia  552484    cross reference definitions and rules of construction  12 territorial application this article applies to rental agreements wherever made for dwelling units within the city with such exemptions as are set forth in virginia  552485    functions a conflicts in landlordtenant relationships arising out of the application of the virginia residential landlord and tenant act regarding dwelling units located within the city may be submitted to the city housing commission the housing commission is authorized to mediate such conflicts as is permitted by the virginia  552482 et seq and is authorized to provide arbitration as is permitted by state law b the housing commission shall have the assistance of staff designated by the city manager and may also avail itself of the services of the city attorney    procedure complaints alleging conflict in the application of the virginia residential landlord and tenant act shall be received and processed pursuant to procedures rules and regulations provided herein and those which the housing commission shall establish from time to time    staff processing of complaints a complaints alleging conflict shall be made initially to the staff representative upon receiving the complaint the staff representative shall make such investigation as is necessary and appropriate to ascertain the facts and shall make every reasonable effort to resolve the conflict or shall refer the complaint to the proper authority the staff representative shall maintain a record specifying the names addresses nature of the conflict all action taken on the conflict and all action taken toward its resolution b if the staff representative is unable to resolve the conflict the parties upon mutual agreement may elect to submit the conflict to the housing commission for either mediation pursuant to section 22132 or arbitration pursuant to section 22133 if the parties elect to submit the conflict to the housing commission the staff representative shall then submit the record of the complaint to the housing commission in writing with copies also being provided to the parties    mediation the housing commission shall review the report of the staff representative meet with the parties to hear their views and recommend such reconciliatory action as the housing commission deems appropriate if reconciliation is reached the terms thereof shall be reduced to writing and incorporated into a stipulation of settlement signed by the parties this stipulation is for reconciliation purposes only and does not constitute an admission by any party that any law has been violated such stipulation of settlement shall be filed with and maintained by the housing commission    arbitration a the housing commission shall provide arbitration pursuant to rules and regulations set forth by the housing commission and those specified by the virginia should the parties mutually agree to this procedure its consequences shall be binding upon them in accordance with the virginia such settlements are enforceable in court b the terms of any arbitration settlement shall be filed with and maintained by the housing commission    rules and regulations for landlordtenant proceedings a the housing commission shall send sufficient notification of the time and place of any mediation or arbitration proceedings to the parties b during the proceedings the parties shall at their option appear before the housing commission in person or be represented by duly authorized representatives and may have the assistance of an attorney c the parties or their authorized representatives may present testimony and evidence and the right to cross examine witnesses shall be preserved d the parties or their authorized representatives may file such statements with the housing commission as they deem necessary e the housing commission shall not be bound by strict rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity f the housing commission shall maintain a record of the proceedings upon request by any party the housing commission shall furnish a copy of the record at such cost as it deems appropriate    disclosure of information a all information relevant to a complaint under this article shall be held confidential by the housing commission until the proceedings before the housing commission shall be concluded or reconciliation is reached unless the parties agree in writing to disclosure of such information b nothing in this article shall contravene the virginia freedom of information act    other remedies nothing herein shall prevent any person from exercising any rights or seeking any remedy to which that person might otherwise be entitled    libraries footnotes  1  charter reference authority of city to provide or support public for violations of  state law reference penalty for violation of traffic laws virginia  462113 traffic emergencies a in the interest of preserving the safety health and welfare of the public under conditions of danger to persons or property specified in this subsection the city manager in his sole discretion may declare a state of traffic emergency and make effective certain regulations affecting the operation and parking of motor vehicles in and on the city streets as designed by the city manager these conditions and the regulations in effect during the period of traffic emergency are as follows the city manager shall have the authority to declare a traffic emergency upon the announcement of a winter storm warning by the us weather bureau or a similar professional weather forecasting service the emergency shall become effective upon the notification to at least three radio stations whose broadcast areas include the city the emergency shall remain effective until rescinded by the city manager same procedure the city manager shall have the authority to designate and post with appropriate signs snow emergency routes b during a traffic emergency it shall be unlawful for any person to 1 obstruct or impede traffic on a street designated and posted as a snow emergency route by reason of the failure of that person to have the vehicle operated by him equipped on the drive wheels with snow or allweather tires or snow chains  or 2 to abandon or park a motor vehicle on a street designated and posted as a snow emergency route motor vehicles that are stalled stuck parked or abandoned on a street designated and posted as a snow emergency route may be towed and stored at the direction of the police department with all reasonable costs being charged to the owner of the vehicle c upon conviction of a violation of subsection b of this section the penalty shall be no less than $5000 d in order to permit the removal of accumulations of snow the city manager shall have the authority to designate and post streets for a temporary period so that parking or abandoning a vehicle is prohibited it shall be unlawful to park or abandon a vehicle on a street when so designated and posted any vehicle in violation may be removed and stored at the direction of the police with all reasonable costs charged to the owner of the vehicle no vehicle shall be removed unless the street has been so designated and conspicuously posted for at least 24 hours upon conviction the penalty for violation of this subsection d shall be a fine of no less than $2000 nor more than $2500 e in any prosecution under subsections b2 or d of this section where the identity of the driver is not known to the charging officer proof that the vehicle described in the complaint summons or warrant was parked or abandoned in violation of subsections b2 or d of this section together with proof that the defendant was at the time of such offense the registered owner of the vehicle shall constitute a prima facie presumption that such registered owner of the vehicle was the person who parked the vehicle at the location and time during which the offense occurred        state law reference authority to adopt regulation regarding operation of vehicles in snow sleet hail freezing rain ice water flood high wind storm or the threat thereof virginia  4621302 removal and disposition of unattended or abandoned vehicles a whenever any motor vehicle trailer or semitrailer is 1 found on the streets of the city or public grounds which vehicle is unattended by the owner or operator and constitutes a hazard to traffic or is parked in such manner as to be in violation of law  2 left unattended for more than 48 hours upon any street or publicly owned property or upon any privately owned property other than the property of the owner of such motor vehicle trailer or semitrailer within the city  or 3 abandoned upon such privately owned property without the permission of the owner lessee or occupant regardless of whether it was brought onto the private property with the consent of the owner or person in control of the private property  any such motor vehicle trailer or semitrailer may be removed for safekeeping by or under the direction of a police officer to a storage garage or area  provided no such vehicle shall be removed from a privately owned premises without the written request of the owner lessee or occupant when the owner lessee or occupant of such privately owned property requests such removal he shall be required to indemnify the city against any loss or expense involved by reason of removal storage or sale each removal shall be reported to the chief of police and notice given to the owner of the motor vehicle trailer or semitrailer as promptly as possible b the owner of an unattended or abandoned vehicle trailer or semitrailer before obtaining possession shall pay to the parties entitled thereto all reasonable costs incidental to the removal storage and locating the owner of the motor vehicle trailer or semitrailer c should the owner of an unattended or abandoned vehicle fail or refuse to pay the costs or should the identity or whereabouts of such owner be unknown or unascertainable after a diligent search has been made and after notice to him at his last known address and to the holder of any lien of record in the office of the division of motor vehicles against the motor vehicle trailer or semitrailer the chief of police or his duly designated agent may after holding the motor vehicle trailer or semitrailer 40 days and after due notice of sale dispose of the same at public sale and the proceeds of the sale shall be forwarded by the selling officer to the treasurer of the city the treasurer shall pay from the proceeds of the sale the cost of removal storage investigation as to ownership and liens and notice of sale and the balance of such funds shall be held by him for the owner and paid to the owner upon satisfactory proof of ownership d it shall be presumed that the motor vehicle trailer or semitrailer or part thereof is abandoned if 1 it lacks a a current license plate  b a current city sticker  or c a valid state inspection certificate or sticker  and 2 it has been in a specific location for ten days without being moved e if no claim has been made by the owner for the proceeds of such sale after the payment of the abovementioned cost the funds may be deposited to the general fund or any special fund of the city any such owner shall be entitled to apply to the city for such funds within three years from the date of the sale and if timely application is made the city shall pay the same to the owner without interest or charges no claim shall be made nor shall any suit action or violations or monetary penalties imposed j when selecting potential intersections for a traffic light signal violation monitoring system the city shall consider factors such as 1 the accident rate for the intersection  2 the rate of red light violations occurring at the intersection number of violations per number of vehicles  3 the difficulty experienced by law enforcement officers in patrol cars or on foot in apprehending violators  and 4 the ability of law enforcement officers to apprehend violators safely within a reasonable distance from the violation the city may consider the risk to pedestrians as a factor if applicable the city shall submit a list of intersections to the virginia department of transportation for final approval k before the implementation of a traffic light yellow phase shall be established based on the recommended methodology of the institute of transportation engineers all traffic light signal violation monitoring systems shall provide a minimum issuance or removal of onstreet residential parking restrictions a the city manager shall designate new parking restrictions or remove existing parking restrictions on streets within a district where residential uses are permitted according to the following process 1 initiation an individual citizen groups of citizens civic association business developer city staff or the city council may initiate a request for the addition or removal of parking restrictions written request to staff 2 petition staff will provide the petitioner with a request for restricted parking petition form the petitioner is required to obtain signatures of support for parking restrictions on a block from a minimum of 75 percent of the households located on the block if a minimum of 75 percent of the households sign the petition indicating support for adding or removing parking restrictions on that block then data collection will begin 3 data collection the police department will conduct field observations over a oneweek period the following guidelines will be considered when evaluating the block a fifty percent of the available parking spaces on that block are filled b twentyfive percent of those vehicles are from outside the city 4 decision the city manager shall decide based on the police department survey and the neighborhood petition whether or not to designate the area under consideration as a restricted area or to remove the designation in the case of an established restricted area a parking restrictions in residential districts abutting metro stations shall limit onstreet parking to four hours unless otherwise determined by the city manager b parking restrictions in residential districts abutting commercial corridors shall limit onstreet parking to two hours unless otherwise determined by the city manager c current parking restrictions shall remain in effect unless a petition is filed by the parties named in subsection a1 of this section requesting the city managers office review a change to the existing designation 5 notice the decision of the city manager shall be announced notification of property owners within the boundaries of the restricted area the notice shall clearly state the exact location and boundaries of the restricted area and the reasons why such area has been designated or withdrawn as a restricted parking area in addition to property owner notification a similar notification shall be prominently posted within the area for ten days prior to the installation of parking signs b proof of registration as indicated by a city registration decal shall serve as the parking permit and shall exempt vehicles from residential parking restrictions except that in parking zones for which a separate parking permit sticker or placard is issued by the city no vehicle shall be exempt from such restrictions unless such vehicle displays a cityissued sticker or placard c on the application of any resident of the district the chief of police or his authorized designee may issue visitors permits upon a showing by the resident that during the hours for which the permits are sought his residence will be used in such a way consistent with its residential character and other provisions of law that visitors to his residence would not be able to park without violating the law if the chief of police shall find the foregoing facts and further find that the issuance of the permits will not unduly impair traffic safety during the time of their validity he shall issue such permits and may limit the streets or portions of streets on which they bicycle paths a established the existing and approved bikeways within the city which have been established by the northern virginia regional park authority or by the city and any bikeways which are in the future established by the northern virginia regional park authority or the city are hereby established as the bikeways of the city b vehicles prohibited  city and park authority vehicles exempted offstreet bikeways for maintenance fire and police patrol purposes c exceptions for vehicles used by handicapped persons the prohibitions of this section do not apply to vehicles being used by persons with disabilities when such use is necessary because of the handicapped condition of the person using such vehicle      riding and parking regulations every person riding a bicycle upon a bikeway sidewalk street highway or roadway has all the rights and is subject to all the duties applicable to the driver of a motor vehicle except those provisions which by their very nature can have no application additionally every such person shall comply with the following 1 speed no bicycle shall be operated faster than is reasonable and proper but every bicycle shall be operated with reasonable regard for the safety of the operator and every other person upon the streets sidewalks highways roadways and bikeways of the city 2 observation of traffic regulations every person riding a bicycle in the city shall observe all authorized traffic signs signals and traffic control devices whenever signs are erected indicating that no right turn or left turn or uturn is permitted no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the direction of any such signs except where such persons dismount from the bicycle to make any such movements or turns  in which event such a person shall then obey the regulation applicable to pedestrians 3 stop signs all persons operating a bicycle shall stop at all stop signs 4 riding with the traffic flow every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practical exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction 5 riding on handlebars no person operating a bicycle shall permit any person to ride on the handlebars 6 interference with control no person operating a bicycle shall carry any package bundle or article which prevents that person from keeping at least one hand firmly upon the handlebars and in full control of the bicycle 7 hitching rides no person riding upon any bicycle shall attach the same or self to any vehicle on the roadway 8 riding abreast bicycles shall be ridden or operated in a single file except when overtaking a slower moving bicycle and except on bikeways set aside for the use of bicycles 9 riding on sidewalk persons of any age may ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk except as otherwise prohibited in section 26110 and except in those areas designated as unsafe by the city manager because of the narrowness of the sidewalk slope of the sidewalk number of pedestrians customarily using the sidewalk or potential vehicle conflict 10 pedestrian rightofway whenever any person shall ride a bicycle on the sidewalk or bikeway whether paved or unpaved such person shall yield the rightofway to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing any pedestrian 11 bicycle lane where the city council has by ordinance designated a lane for the exclusive use of bicycles a motor vehicle may enter or cross this lane for the purpose of access to adjacent property or for the purpose of parking but a motor vehicle shall not be driven in this lane 12 parking no person shall stand or park a bicycle upon the street highway or roadway other than upon the street highway or roadway against the curb no person shall stand or park a bicycle upon the sidewalk or bikeway other than in a rack to support the bicycle or against the building or at the curb or at the back edge of the sidewalk this will be done in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic 13 riding on paths adjacent to a roadway whenever a usable path or designated bikeway has been provided adjacent to a roadway bicycle riders shall use such path or bikeway and shall not use the roadway 14 helmet required every person 14 years of age or younger shall wear a protective helmet that meets the us consumer product safety commission safety standard for bicycle helmets whenever riding or being carried on a bicycle an electric personal assistive mobility device a toy vehicle or an electric powerassisted bicycle on any highway sidewalk or public bicycle path        riding or driving on sidewalks the city manager upon the request of any owner of any property adjacent to any public sidewalk may prohibit or restrict the use of such sidewalks by persons riding bicycles  provided such restrictions are posted  and further provided that children who have not attained their 13th birthday are not prohibited in for a continuous period of at least ten minutes  and 3 a written record shall be made by the person using an immobilization device immediately after the immobilization device has been used showing the the signature of the person who made the determination that immobilization was authorized these records shall be provided to the city manager on a monthly basis on a form provided by the city manager immobilized by any owner or operator or their agent  nor shall any vehicle parked or left temporarily because of a wreck or other emergency be immobilized c a $50000 cash bond shall be posted with the city manager by any person desiring to use one or more immobilization device prior to such use anyone complaining that the persons use of the device violated any provision of this section may apply in writing to the city manager for reimbursement of any fees charged for the immobilization the city manager shall make a determination as to whether for the civil purpose of the bond a violation has occurred and if the city manager finds by a preponderance of the evidence that a violation has occurred the city manager shall award a reimbursement of the charge levied for removal of the device prior to any determination the person posting the bond shall have notice of the complaint and an opportunity to be heard complaints must be filed with the manager no later than 30 days after the alleged violation if the bond amount falls below $40000 at any time the person posting the bond shall be notified  and if the amount of the bond is not raised to $50000 within 14 days of the notice having been mailed the right to use an immobilization device shall cease d any person convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $100000 or one year 36 state law reference drinking alcoholic beverages in public places virginia  1308 defacement of property a purpose and intent it is the purpose and intent of this section to provide a procedure for removal or repair of defacement including graffiti from public and private property to protect the public health safety and welfare and to reduce blight and the deterioration of property within the city b definitions for the purposes of this section the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section 1 city manager means the city manager of the city or his designee 2 defacement means spoiling the appearance disfiguring marring or making illegible by injuring the surface of public or private property defacement includes the placement of graffiti on such property 3 graffiti means the unauthorized application of any writing painting drawing etching scratching or marking of an inscription word figure or design of any type on any public or private building or other real or personal property owned operated or maintained by a governmental entity or an agency or instrumentality thereof or by any private person firm or corporation 4 placement of graffiti means any form or act of drawing painting scrawling writing marking inscribing scratching gluing posting or otherwise affixing graffiti to public or private property 5 public or private property means the exterior surface of any building wall fence structure or any street alley sidewalk or other vehicular or pedestrian rightofway or any article of street furniture utility or public service equipment or other personal property located outdoors whether owned by a public entity or by a private person or entity and visible from any public rightofway c violation as public nuisance the failure of any owner of public or private property to remove or repair defacement from such property or to permit removal or repair of the defacement after notice as provided in this section is declared to be a public nuisance d removal or repair of defacement 1 notice and opportunity to remove or repair whenever the city manager becomes aware of the existence of defacement on any public or private property the city manager or designee may give or cause to be given to the property owner written notice to remove or repair the defacement such notice shall be served either by personal delivery or by certified mail and shall be effective upon delivery or mailing such notice shall request the property owner to remove or repair the defacement within 15 calendar days after the effective date of the notice such notice further shall seek the owners written permission for the city to enter upon the property to remove or repair the defacement such notice further shall inform the property owner that if the property owner fails to comply with the notice then the city may maintain a public nuisance action against the property owner to compel the property owner to allow for the removal or repair of the defacement before issuing a notice under this subsection the city manager shall contact the owner and manager or occupant of the property and attempt to obtain a commitment to remove or repair the defacement within a reasonable period of time if no such commitment is made or if made the commitment is not honored within a reasonable period of time as determined by the city manager then the manager may issue a notice described in this subsection 2 removal or repair by city if the owner of the property upon which the defacement exists fails to remove or repair the defacement or grant written permission to the city to enter upon the property to remove or repair the defacement within 15 calendar days after the effective date of the notice described in subsection d1 of this section the city its agents or employees may enter upon the property and remove the defacement such agents or employees shall have any and all immunity normally provided to an employee of the city the city may also impose a fine of $1000 per day for every day that the defacement remains on the property after the effective date of the notice described in subsection d1 of this section 3 the city manager or a designated representative is authorized to undertake or contract for the removal or repair of the defacement by or application of graffiti of any public building wall fence or other structure or of any private building wall fence or other structure where such graffiti is visible from any public rightofway 4 prior to such removal the city manager or a designated representative shall seek the written permission of the property owner should the property owner fail to provide such permission within 15 days after the request the city may have such defacement removed or repaired by the citys agents or employees 5 all such removal or repair may be at the expense of the city in the citys discretion  provided however that the removal or repair work may be undertaken by volunteers or individuals required to perform community service by order of any court under appropriate city supervision 6 after inspection of an unoccupied public or private property if a violation exists the community services officer or designee shall post the notice of violation in a conspicuous place upon the land or premises and shall send a copy of such notice by certified or registered mail to the owner of records last known address as shown on the city tax records the notice of violation shall direct the owner to remove or repair the defacement from such public or private property within 15 days of service of the notice of violation after such notice of violation is served on the owner and such violation has not been corrected within 15 days of service of the notice of violation the community services officer or designee may proceed to remedy the violation as provided in subsection d7 unless the notice of violation has been appealed under subsection d8 7 if the defacement is not removed or repaired from the property within the time required by the notice of violation issued pursuant to subsection d6 the community services officer or designee may proceed to have the defacement removed the costs and expenses for the removal shall be chargeable to and paid by the owner of such property the costs and expenses may be collected by the city as taxes and levies are collected if an appeal is filed under subsection d8 the defacement shall not be removed until a decision on the appeal has been made by the city manager 8 any owner who is aggrieved by the notice of violation pursuant to subsections d2 or d6 may within ten days of service of the notice of violation appeal to the city manager or his designee by submitting to the city manager or his designee and a copy to the community services officer a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal the city manager or his designee shall make a finding on the appeal based on the written statement provided by the property owner and information provided by the community services officer until the decision is made by the city manager no action shall be taken 3122007 secs 3053053  reserved article ii  grievances eligibility a all nonprobationary regular fulltime and parttime employees working 20 or more hours weekly are eligible to file grievances with the exception of the 1 city manager 2 city attorney 3 city clerk 4 elected and appointed state and local officials 5 employees of constitutional officers 6 temporary term grant and seasonal employees b the exceptions listed in subsection a of this section do not apply to a city employee if the complaint includes allegations of discrimination on the basis of race color creed religion age disability national origin gender political affiliation sexual orientation or marital status c leadership team employees grievance rights are limited in that they may not grieve termination or demotion with the exception of police captains d law enforcement officers as defined in virginia  91500 who have a grievance may proceed under the guidelines cited in the law enforcement officers procedural guarantee act virginia  91500 et seq or under the citys grievance procedure but not both  3122007 types of grievances a grievance may include but is not necessarily limited to 1 disciplinary actions involving dismissals demotions and suspensions provided that the dismissals shall be grievable whenever resulting from formal discipline or unsatisfactory job performance 2 the application meaning or interpretation of personnel policies procedures rules and regulations 3 complaint of discrimination on the basis of race color creed religion political affiliation age gender disability national origin sexual orientation or marital status 4 sexual harassment 5 acts of retaliation as the result of the use of or participation in the grievance procedure or because the employee complied with any law of the united states or of the commonwealth has reported any violation of such governmental authority has sought any change in law before the congress of the united states or the general assembly or has reported an incidence of fraud abuse or gross mismanagement to a city councilmember the city manager or other governmental authority 6 retaliation for exercising any rights otherwise protected by law  3122007 nongrievable actions a a grievance shall not be interpreted to include 1 the contents of ordinances statutes or established personnel policies rules and regulations 2 work activity accepted by the employee as a condition of employment or work activity which may be reasonably expected to be a part of the job description 3 establishment and revisions of wages or salaries position classifications or general benefits 4 failure to promote except where the employee can show established promotional policies or procedures were not followed or applied fairly 5 the methods means and personnel by which such work activities are to be completed 6 discharge demotion or layoff because of lack of work reduction in workforce or job abolition except where such action affects an employee who has been reinstated within the previous six months as a result of the final determination of a grievance 7 the hiring promotion transfer assignment and retention of employees within the city 8 the relief of employees from duties in emergencies 9 oral reprimands 10 decisions of a performance evaluation appeals panel b in any grievance brought under the exception to subsection a5 of this section the action shall be upheld upon a showing by the city that there was a valid business reason for the action and the employee was notified of such reason in writing prior to the effective date of the action  3122007 grievability determinations a decisions regarding whether or not a matter is grievable shall be made by the city manager at the request of the grievant or the department on the appropriate form such determination of grievability shall be made subsequent to the placement of the grievance in writing but prior to a hearing before the city employee review board the form bearing the decision of the city manager must be returned to the grievant within 14 calendar days after receipt of the request b the issue of grievability may be raised at any step of the procedure prior to a hearing before the board  but once raised the issue must be resolved before further processing of the grievance in any event the issue of grievability must be resolved prior to a board hearing or it shall be deemed to have been waived c the city managers decision regarding grievability may be appealed to the county circuit court for a hearing de novo on the issue of grievability as provided in section 1521507 a9a of the virginia virginia  1521507 a9a as amended such appeal shall be noted by returning the grievability form to the city manager within 14 calendar days after receipt of the initial decision on grievability within 14 calendar days thereafter the city manager shall transmit the record including copies of the decision of the city manager the notice of appeal and any exhibits to the clerk of the county circuit court the procedure for the conduct of the appeal shall be provided for in section 1521507 a9a and b of the virginia virginia  1521507 a9a b as amended the decision of the court is final and is not appealable  3122007 procedure employee grievances whether by an individual or a group of employees shall be processed as follows 1 step 1 supervisory level a grievance must be raised within 20 calendar days after the occurrence or condition giving rise to the grievance or within 20 calendar days following the time the employee knows or should have known of its occurrence a a grievant shall discuss the matter with the grievants immediate supervisor who shall attempt to resolve the matter informally within five calendar days of such discussion the supervisor shall give response to the employee with respect to the grievance or shall advise the employee that additional time for such decision is needed in which case a decision must be given to the employee within five calendar days thereafter b if a satisfactory resolution is not reached by this process the employee may put the grievance in writing on the approved city form stating the nature of the grievance and the expected remedy such written grievance shall be presented to the next level of supervision within ten calendar days after notice of the decision of the immediate supervisor the second level supervisor shall hold a meeting with the employee and render a written decision within seven calendar days of receipt of the appeal if the second level supervisor is the general manager step 1 part b and step 2 are consolidated into a single step 2 step 2 management level if the grievant is not satisfied with the decision of the second level supervisor the grievant may submit the grievance to the general manager within 15 calendar days of the reply received from step 1 part b as set forth in subsection 1b of this section at least three calendar days prior to the hearing all documents exhibits and lists of witnesses shall be exchanged between the parties the general manager shall hear the appeal within ten calendar days of receipt of the request and shall render a written decision to the grievant within five calendar days following the hearing if the supervisor is the city manager steps 2 and 3 as set forth in this subsection and subsection 3 of this section are consolidated into a single step 3 step 3 city manager if the grievant is not satisfied with the decision of the general manager the grievant may file a written appeal to the city manager within 21 calendar days of receipt of the decision in step 2 as set forth in subsection 2 of this section at least three calendar days prior to the hearing all documents exhibits and lists of witnesses shall be exchanged between the parties the city manager shall hear the grievant within 14 calendar days of receipt of the request and render a written decision within an additional seven calendar days after completion of the hearing 4 step 4 board hearing a if the grievant is not satisfied with the decision of the city manager he may file a written appeal on the appropriate city form to the city employees review board via the chairman within 14 calendar days of receipt of the city managers decision the city employees review board shall hear the appeal within 40 calendar days of receipt b at least ten calendar days before a scheduled hearing the grievant and such grievants attorney shall be allowed access to and copies of all relevant files intended to be used in the grievance hearing and all documents exhibits and lists of witnesses shall be exchanged between the parties c the board has the responsibility to interpret the application of appropriate city or department policies and procedures in the case it does not have the prerogative to formulate or to change policies or procedures a quorum of the board shall consist of all three members d the city employees review board shall render a written decision within 14 calendar days after completion of the hearing and it shall be filed by the chairman with the city manager the majority decision of the board shall be final and binding in all the determinations and shall be consistent with the provisions of law and written policies copies of the decision shall be transmitted to the director of human resources the employee and the employees supervisors via the general manager either party to the grievance may petition the county circuit court for an order requiring implementation of the decision of the board 5 personal face to face meetings are required at steps 1 as set forth in subsections 1 3 of this section  3122007 employee review board a the board shall be composed of three members who are citizens of the city and are appointed by the city council the members shall be appointed for staggered threeyear terms and shall elect a chairman annually within two months following either the annual appointment of new fulltime members or the anniversary of their appointment members shall serve without compensation in addition to serving as the final appeal board for grievance procedures the board shall serve as the selection committee for the city employee of the year program b the board shall not be composed of any persons having direct involvement with the grievance being heard by the board or with the complaint or dispute giving rise to the grievance managers who are in a direct line of supervision of a grievant and the following relatives of a participant in the grievance process or a participants spouse are prohibited from serving as board members spouse parent and child descendants of a child sibling niece nephew and first cousin no attorney having direct involvement with the subject matter of the grievance nor a partner associate employee or coemployee of such an attorney shall serve as a board member  3122007 employee representation the employee shall be permitted to be accompanied or represented by an individual of such employees choice at step 1 part b as set forth in section 30581b and any subsequent steps in the grievance procedure the second level supervisor general manager or city manager may have a witness of choice likewise in attendance at any meeting if an employee using the grievance procedure elects to have legal counsel representation the employee shall be responsible for the related expenses  3122007 mediation mediation is a voluntary process and employees or supervisors may initiate a request for mediation to the citys human resources director the human resources director will meet with the employees interested in mediation to explain the process determine their commitment to reaching a resolution and to assess the appropriateness of the issue for mediation if mediation is requested prior to the initiation of a grievance the employee may request an extension of the initial filing period if the request for mediation is made during the course of a grievance the applicable time periods are extended until the conclusion of the mediation process upon conclusion of the mediation process and the resulting written agreement that both parties to the complaint or dispute sign an employee may agree that a written grievance will not be initiated or that a grievance in progress will be concluded the city manager shall provide an administrative regulation setting forth the mediation procedure  3122007 waiver of time limits by mutual agreement in writing the parties to a grievance at any and every step may extend any or all of the time periods established in the procedures  3122007 failure to comply with procedural requirements after the initial filing of a written grievance failure of either party to comply with all substantial procedural requirements of the grievance procedure without just cause will result in a decision in favor of the other party on any grievable issue provided the party not in compliance fails to correct the noncompliance within five work days of receipt of written notification by the other party of the compliance violation such written notification by the grievant shall be made to the city manager failure of either party without just cause to comply with all substantial procedural requirements at the board hearing shall result in a decision in favor of the other party compliance determinations made by the city manager shall be subject to judicial review by filing a petition with the circuit court within 30 days of the compliance determination  3122007 management rights and maintenance and analysis of records a nothing in the procedure is intended to circumscribe or modify the existing management right of the city to do the following 1 direct the work of its employees as well as establish and revise wages salaries position classifications and general employee benefits 2 hire promote transfer assign and retain employees within the city 3 maintain the efficiency of governmental operations 4 relieve employees from duties in emergencies 5 determine the methods means and personnel by which operations are to be carried on b records relating to a grievance including all written statements forms investigations and exhibits are maintained in the human resources division such information is protected by the privacy act of virginia and access to the records is limited accordingly the director of human resources shall conduct an annual review of all grievances filed and make a written report by each february 1 to the city manager should a trend after analysis require action to minimize the causes of such grievances in the future  3122007 secs 30653086  reserved article iii  layoffs and transfers use of layoff procedure the city manager may invoke a layoff procedure when such manager determines that there are an excess number of employees as a result of the abolishment of a position reorganization of functions the lack of funds or the lack of or curtailment of work  3122007 determination of employees to be laidoff a it is the responsibility of the director of human resources to develop layoff registers for each classification in which the city manager has invoked a layoff procedure each layoff register shall be divided into three categories and these shall be utilized in the separation of excess employees these categories are 1 first category temporary employees 2 second category probationary employees 3 third category permanent status employees b within each classification in which a layoff procedure has been invoked all employees in the first category shall be separated prior to separating any employees from the second category and similarly all employees in the second category shall be separated prior to separating any permanent status employees in the third category  3122007 development of layoff register a first category the names of employees in the first category shall be placed on the list in alphabetical order no layoff rating value shall be assigned to these employees and the order of separation within this category shall be at the determination of the general manager b second category the names of employees in the second category shall be placed on the list in alphabetical order no layoff rating value shall be assigned to these employees and the order of separation within this category shall be at the determination of the general manager c third category each permanent status employee shall have a layoff rating value assigned by the director of human resources which will determine that employees place within the category the layoff rating value shall be a combination of months of creditable service with the city and an average performance evaluation score apes for the official performance evaluation ratings received within the last five years the points assigned for months of service shall equal 40 percent of the total score while the points assigned for the average performance evaluation score shall equal 60 percent of the total point value the procedure is as follows 1 points for service one point is given for each full month of creditable service with the city 2 points for performance evaluation rating an examination shall be made of the employees annual performance evaluation ratings andor the evaluation ratings completed prior to a promotiondemotion action dating back for no more than five years of creditable service each evaluation shall be assigned points as follows a three points for each exceeds expectations rating b two points for each above expectations rating c one point for each meets expectations rating d zero points for each needs improvement or below expectations rating the total points assigned are added together and then divided by the number of evaluations used to obtain the average performance evaluation score apes 3 formula to calculate the layoff rating value number of months of creditable service x 04 + the sum of points received for performance evaluations within the last five years  ds  by number of evaluations x 06 4 separation of employees in third category separation of employees in the third category shall be in the order of those with the least layoff rating value on the layoff register to those with the highest layoff rating value if two employees have the same layoff rating value separation shall be at the determination of the general manager taking into account any special skills or training the employee may possess  3122007 transfer in lieu of layoff a an employee designated as excess shall be transferred to a position in the same class which may be vacant in another city department or division if not accepted within five working days of the offer the employee shall be deemed terminated an excess employee may request a transfer to another class in the citys classification plan for which there is a vacancy provided all the qualifications are met if the vacancy is in a higher classified position the employee designated as excess will be subject to the selection procedures in the citys administrative regulations applications for such transfers are voluntary b if a lateral transfer is not available an employee shall be transferred to a lower classified position the employee shall be placed in the new salary level equal to the employees current rate of pay this transfer could involve a gradual pay reduction if not accepted within five working days of the offer the employee shall be deemed terminated when the employees rate of pay prior to transfer exceeds the maximum step of the new lower salary level the employees rate of pay shall be frozen at that existing rate for six months until the pay of the lower salary level matches or exceeds the employees rate of pay from the time of the transfer after six months the employee shall receive a reduction in pay equal to five percent and shall be assigned to a salary level corresponding to this rate of pay if possible if the employees rate of pay following the five percent reduction exceeds the maximum rate of pay for the salary level the employees rate of pay shall be frozen again for a second sixmonth period at the end of the second six months the employees rate of pay shall be reduced again by five percent and if it still exceeds the maximum rate of pay it shall be frozen and then reduced by five percent in six month intervals until the maximum rate of pay for that salary level is achieved the anniversary date shall not change  3122007 reemployment list a if there are no transfer opportunities an excess employee in the second or third category of the layoff register shall be placed on a reemployment list for that class for a period of one year from layoff if the excess employee on the reemployment list does not accept the first available permanent status vacancy of the same class as that from which he had been laid off that occurs within the year the employee shall be removed from the reemployment list and may apply at any time for future city employment subject to the selection procedures in the personnel regulations b vacancies in lower classes in the same class series shall also be offered during the period the excess employee is on the reemployment list if the excess employee meets all the qualifications if an employee is offered and rejects an employment opportunity in a lower class in the class series the employee shall remain eligible for reemployment in such employees same class as that from which the employee had been laid off but will be removed from the reemployment list of the class in which an employment opportunity is rejected an employee who accepts reemployment in a lower graded class shall retain eligibility for reemployment rights within the same class for the oneyear period c temporary positions that become available in that same class will be offered to persons with reemployment rights if an employee accepts a temporary position such employee shall remain eligible for reemployment as described in this section d the city manager is authorized to provide severance pay to regular employees at the rate of pay at the time of layoff based on the regular number of hours worked weekly the amount of severance pay shall be determined by the city manager but shall not exceed six weeks temporary grant and term employees are excluded form eligibility severance pay shall be forfeited by an employee who declines a transfer or reassignment to a position in the same class series where the general terms and conditions of employment are identical to those which the employee enjoyed in the position held prior to layoff the city manager shall establish other rules and regulations dealing with the payment of such severance pay  3122007 notification procedures a general managers whose departments are affected by a layoff shall issue a general notice indicating a layoff procedure is underway this notice is issued when it is not yet determined what individual action shall be taken b prior to layoff a permanent employee shall receive at least 30 calendar days notice a temporary or probationary employee shall receive at least ten calendar days notice c the employees specific notice of layoff shall be accomplished in a written communication from the employees general manager notifying such employee of the layoff and the reasons for it the communication may be either handdelivered or sent by certified mail to the employees home address a copy of the communication shall be forwarded to the human resources office  3122007 jobsharing and reduced hours general managers whose departments are affected by a layoff procedure shall consider jobsharing andor reduced working hours in an effort to reduce the number of employees who would otherwise be laidoff a recommendation on the feasibility of jobsharing andor reduced working hours shall be forwarded to the division of human resources with an analysis of the impact on city services rendered fiscal cost comparisons and other pertinent data the city manager shall either approve or deny the recommendation  3122007 secs
